page.title: 16Traditional Craft,Warbleton
page.content: In this era of mass production it is gratifying to find a traditional craftsman in our midst. David Bysouth follows his father and grandfather as a wheelwright. Wheels are made using seasoned elmwood for the hub, oak for the spokes and curved ash or possibly elm "felloes" for the rim. In blacksmith fashion a red hot iron tyre is hammered onto the rim and a cast iron sleeve to the hub. Recent years have seen an increased demand for the wheelwright's skills. Whilst some work involves repairing old wheels,a growing interest in driving horse-drawn vehicles both for competitive sport and leisure, has meant a demand for new wagons and carts. In addition there is an increased desire to restore derelict carriages and vehicles.
